metadata.Title: CVE-2015-4000 on Ubuntu 14.04 ESM (trusty) - medium.
metadata.Description:
The TLS protocol 1.2 and earlier, when a DHE_EXPORT ciphersuite is enabled on a server but not on a client, does not properly convey a DHE_EXPORT choice, which allows man-in-the-middle attackers to conduct cipher-downgrade attacks by rewriting a ClientHello with DHE replaced by DHE_EXPORT and then rewriting a ServerHello with DHE_EXPORT replaced by DHE, aka the "Logjam" issue.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2015-4000` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

libapache2-mod-macro - 2.4.7-1ubuntu4.4
libapache2-mod-proxy-html - 2.4.7-1ubuntu4.4
No subscription required

apache2 - 2.4.7-1ubuntu4.4

notes.Note: mdeslaur> USN-2624-1 disables export ciphers completely in openssl USN-2625-1 disables export ciphers in apache2 in precise seth-arnold> USN-2639-1 disables <768 bit dh parameters in openssl mdeslaur> USN-2672-1 disables <768 bit dh parameters in nss sbeattie> USN-2696-1 disables <768 bit dh parameters in openjdk-7 mdeslaur> gnutls isn't vulnerable to this issue and rejects small dh keys by default. On precise and trusty, the gnutls-cli tool unfortunately sets the minimum dh size to 512 using gnutls_dh_set_prime_bits(), so that must be disabled to test using the command line tool.

criterions.comment: apache2 package in trusty, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '2.4.7-1ubuntu4.4').
apache2 package in trusty, is related to the CVE in some way and has been fixed (note: '2.4.7-1ubuntu4.4').
firefox package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '39.0+build5-0ubuntu0.14.04.1').
nss package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '2:3.19.2-0ubuntu0.14.04.1').
openjdk-6 package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '6b36-1.13.8-0ubuntu1~14.04').
openjdk-7 package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '7u79-2.5.6-0ubuntu1.14.04.1').
openssl package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '1.0.1f-1ubuntu2.12').
openssl098: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support').
thunderbird package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '1:31.8.0+build1-0ubuntu0.14.04.1').
